awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms and Predictability of Interactions between Convectively Coupled Kelvin Waves and African Easterly Waves Leading to Tropical Cyclogenesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Tropical storms and hurricanes in the Atlantic basin impact lives, the economy, and society.  While the ability to forecast the track of tropical cyclones has improved, gaps remain in the knowledge and understanding of their formation or genesis, which is reflected in poorer forecasts.  Recent results suggest that the African easterly waves pathway to genesis in the Atlantic Basin is influenced by the passage of eastward-moving convectively coupled Kelvin Waves.  However, a quantitative assessment of the processes and predictability of these interactions is lacking.  This collaborative research project between the University of Miami and the University at Albany seeks to provide such a quantitative assessment and to seek a more definite answer to an outstanding question in the tropical storm research: "why do some African easterly waves develop into Tropical Cyclone (TC) and others do not?".  The project is divided into three phases.  The first phase will use three decades of observational and reanalysis data to test hypotheses on the physical mechanisms related to the attribution of genesis or lack of genesis to convectively coupled Kelvin Waves, on time scales of 1-3 days.  The second phase will use two decades of archived ensemble forecast data to investigate and quantify the predictability in the context of these physical mechanisms.  The third phase will extend these ideas out to 1-2 weeks, accounting for the roles of the Madden-Julian Oscillation and El Niño and the Southern Oscillation.  One novel aspect of the project is the awareness of the need to take account of convectively coupled Kelvin Wave amplitude and favorability of African Easterly Wave structures for genesis.  A second novel development is to use ensemble forecasts to push the boundaries of predictability, in identifying the extent to which the complex interactions are predictable out to 1-2 weeks, and connecting the predictability ideas to the governing physical mechanisms and large-scale flow regimes.

The research will provide quantitative information to support tropical forecasters.  The research will also bridge the gap between the weather and subseasonal prediction communities by advancing our understanding of science and predictability beyond traditional weather time scales, which is recognized nationally and globally as a priority.  This will lead to the identification of regimes where predictive skill of genesis and tropical cyclone activity is high or low, thereby providing information to forecasters and ultimately the decision makers who take actions based on a potential tropical cyclone threat.  A by-product of the research will be the feedback provided to operational modeling centers on strengths and weaknesses of their ensemble forecasts.  Diagnostic tools developed in this research will be shared with the research community.  The project will also advance Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics education by funding two students to pursue doctoral research, and in advancing new undergraduate and graduate courses on tropical meteorology.  An annual exchange between Miami and Albany will enable the students to visit meteorological centers and facilities in their reciprocal cities.  Undergraduate Honors thesis projects will be developed.  Several outreach activities related to tropical cyclones, aimed at increasing scientific literacy among decision-makers, the media and public will be continued as part of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this collaborative project between the University of Miami and SUNY at Albany concerns the process and predictability of tropical cyclone formation (“genesis”).  Most intense hurricanes in the Atlantic basin develop from African Easterly Waves (AEWs). One key question in this project is about whether genesis can be attributed to interactions between AEWs and Convectively Coupled Kelvin Waves (CCKWs).  An initial study used CCKW software developed at Albany together with 39 years of reanalysis data to provide a comprehensive analysis of AEWs that did not undergo genesis.  When the convectively active phase of a CCKW passed an AEW, it increased the moisture relative to the AEW, although its influence was mostly short-lived.  A follow-up study, which focused on AEWs that underwent genesis, showed that genesis was most likely to occur 1-2 days after the passage of the CCKW.  This study provided new insights on the roles of moisture and convective clouds during genesis.  Next, the inability of conventional AEW trackers to capture weak AEWs in the western Atlantic and Caribbean led to a third study.  This study used novel machine learning tools to exploit archived information from surface analysts at the National Hurricane Center to provide a more comprehensive database of tropical waves.  This technique was also extended to the Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone and the monsoon trough.  In addition to these three studies, operational ensemble forecasts of genesis were evaluated, with the most difficult forecast cases being associated with very weak waves or wave mergers.  Finally, three undergraduate students investigated the climatologies of AEWs and their surroundings.  These studies were done in the context of whether or not the AEWs developed into tropical cyclones, and whether El Niño or La Niña influenced AEW behavior across the Atlantic basin.

 

The broader impacts of the project included the education and training of two Ph.D. students and three undergraduate students.  In addition to the completion of one Ph.D. dissertation to date and three undergraduate Honors theses, the Ph.D. students also contributed to course materials, co-initiated a summer “Hurricane Academy” for high school students, participated in an undergraduate mentorship program, led the advising of an undergraduate on her Honors thesis research, led local community outreach efforts on hurricanes and preparedness (including hosting webinars during the Covid-19 pandemic), convened sessions at American Meteorological Society meetings, and served as a student representative to the school-wide Academic Committee.  Other broader impacts included direct collaborations with the National Hurricane Center and the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts. The research and operational communities also have access to the AEW tracking software and data.  A website with real-time Global Forecast System forecasts of AEW tracks was also developed under this grant.  Finally, a new undergraduate Tropical Weather and Forecasting course was established and has been taught for five years, incorporating materials developed as part of this grant.
